page.title: 07Livestock Farming
page.content: This area favours livestock farming due to high rainfall and heavy soils. Production from the dairy, sheep and beef farms has been greatly increased over the past thirty years by the use of artificial fertilisers and the veterinary control of diseases. Dairy farms produce milk, and heifer calves to rear as replacements. Bull calves are reared to sell to beef farmers. Shorthorn dairy cattle were replaced by Friesians twenty to thirty years ago laeding to a threefold increase in milk production per cow. Beef cattle are fattened locally and suckler cows are kept on the higher farms. Masham and 'Mule' sheep are common for fat lamb and wool production, whilst traditional Swaledales and Dalesbreds are kept on the hills to provide breeding stock for sale.
